
Eager to win, Alex rushed generating RSA keys and reused a prime. The flag is in 6164443625115713761550791650816282952133671345272797996715443653653285707446974189919929478384008038444919538079722583390082093803262630427576098650320121. Can you exploit the flaw and decrypt it?


The flag format is flag{...}
n=6262356448211790561944560629836828147543652245593912793739320691137423971058222819337012093374217457614720403696240774829557575968177198979216687774836281, e=3919809320599939355229455776344587834857922996882068224875800045862380533632225920903237987928349452400457805893288725879979637266617359605178204524541521

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{6197utai}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 6164443625115713761550791650816282952133671345272797996715443653653285707446974189919929478384008038444919538079722583390082093803262630427576098650320121
vulnerability: repeated primes
hint: The RSA modulus n is a perfect square. This often indicates a repeated prime usage vulnerability.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6262356448211790561944560629836828147543652245593912793739320691137423971058222819337012093374217457614720403696240774829557575968177198979216687774836281, e=3919809320599939355229455776344587834857922996882068224875800045862380533632225920903237987928349452400457805893288725879979637266617359605178204524541521
extra_info: p=79135051956840153211005587353296721379845287976784816762104875616239639039659, q=79135051956840153211005587353296721379845287976784816762104875616239639039659, Ï†(n)=6262356448211790561944560629836828147543652245593912793739320691137423971058064549233098413067795446440013810253481084253604006334652989227984208496756964
subtype: repeated_prime_usage
